text: GOVERNOR ROBERT L. EHRLICH, JR.
label: TITLE

text: “FACES OF MARYLAND” SPEECH
label: BODY

text: Joint Session of the Maryland General Assembly
label: BODY

text: January 29, 2003
label: BODY

text: Senate President Mike Miller; Speaker Mike Busch; Members of the General Assembly;
label: BODY

text: Lt. Governor Steele; Chief Judge Bell; Judge Vaughan; Attorney General Joe Curran;
label: BODY

text: Treasurer Nancy Kopp; Comptroller William Donald Schaefer; members of Congress;
label: BODY

text: county executives and mayors; special guests; friends and fellow Marylanders:
label: BODY

text: What a tremendous honor it is to be standing before you today as Maryland’s governor.
label: BODY

text: I am so happy to be here – back with my friends in the Maryland General Assembly.
label: BODY

text: There are so many good, hard working people on both sides of the aisle – all eager to do
label: BODY

text: what’s right for the citizens of Maryland.
label: BODY

text: I served here for eight years – a tremendous experience for a young legislator.   I’ll
label: BODY

text: always cherish the time I spent here.
label: BODY

text: I made great friends and benefited from great mentors.  Many still serve in this body, and
label: BODY

text: others have joined my administration.
label: BODY

text: I experienced how the legislative process works, as well as the importance of principled
label: BODY

text: cooperation.
label: BODY

text: I observed and participated in serious debates about issues that matter to every citizen:
label: BODY

text: crime, drugs, education, healthcare, transportation, tort reform, the Chesapeake Bay, and
label: BODY

text: juvenile justice.
label: BODY

text: The Maryland General Assembly represents everything that a citizen legislature should
label: BODY

text: be: diverse, collegial, effective, informed and vigilant.  Serving here prepared me for the
label: BODY

text: challenges and demands of being an effective public servant.
label: BODY

text: To all the freshmen members of the Assembly, I encourage you to savor this experience.
label: BODY

text: I also encourage you to make the most of it.  You can do that by getting to know some of
label: BODY

text: the veteran members.  Neither party has a monopoly on talent in this legislature.
label: BODY

text: Many of the people in this room represent the best of public service:  I would like to
label: BODY

text: single out seven of these long-serving members today.
label: BODY

text: Together these members have won 126 races and served a total of 225 years in this
label: BODY

text: historic Assembly.
label: BODY

text: Please stand as I call your name.
label: BODY

text: Delegate Wade Kach: 28 years of service.
label: BODY

text: Delegate Joe Vallario: 28 years of service.
label: BODY

text: Delegate Hattie N. Harrison: 30 years of service.
label: BODY

text: Delegate John Arnick: 31 years of service.
label: BODY

text: Delegate Pauline Menes: 36 years of servic
label: BODY

text: Senator Norman Stone: 40 years of service.
label: HH1

text: Senate President Mike Miller: 32 years of service.
label: BODY

text: It’s appropriate to celebrate public service, and the thoughtful people who choose to
label: BODY

text: serve.  They symbolize what is good and decent about this historic citizen legislature, and
label: BODY

text: we thank them.
label: BODY

text: Maryland continues to be an intellectual force powering the region.  We possess
label: BODY

text: exceptional institutions of higher education such as Johns Hopkins University and the
label: BODY

text: University of Maryland.
label: BODY

text: In the field of medical research, Maryland is an international leader, as demonstrated by
label: BODY

text: the world-renowned Johns Hopkins Medicine, University of Maryland Medical Systems,
label: BODY

text: and National Institutes of Health.
label: BODY

text: Further, NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center and the National Aquarium in Baltimore
label: BODY

text: both speak to the state’s reputation as a science center.
label: BODY

text: The Port of Baltimore is world famous, and we are the center of the biotechnology
label: BODY

text: universe.
label: BODY

text: Our citizens are highly educated, and our per capita personal income is the sixth highest
label: BODY

text: in the nation.
label: BODY

text: As citizens of Maryland, we have a lot in which we can take pride.  Still, there are areas
label: BODY

text: in which we can do better.
label: BODY

text: We need to make our streets and communities safer.  According to FBI statistics,
label: BODY

text: Maryland continues to be one of the most violent states in the nation.
label: BODY

text: Further, the link between crime and drugs remains unbreakable.  A 2001 study performed
label: BODY

text: at Baltimore City’s central booking facility found that nearly three-quarters of arrestees
label: BODY

text: tested positive for at least one drug.
label: BODY

text: While the need for drug treatment programs is high, the need is not currently being met.
label: BODY

text: Presently, there are 7,500 taxpayer-funded treatment programs in Baltimore City, and an
label: BODY

text: estimated 55,000 people requiring treatment.
label: BODY

text: When it comes to the environment, there are challenges waiting for us, too.
label: BODY

text: Despite millions of dollars invested in environmental clean up, the health of the
label: BODY

text: Chesapeake Bay is precarious.
label: BODY

text: A 2002 study by the Chesapeake Bay Foundation found that the Bay’s health, which
label: BODY

text: scored 27 out of 100 in 1998, achieved the same low score in 2002.
label: BODY

text: You’ve heard me recite a number of statistics.  Statistics are serious business.
label: BODY

text: Sometimes, they can be downright scary.  But let me ask you to set them aside for a
label: BODY

text: moment, and consider the people behind the numbers.
label: BODY

text: Many of the issues facing us seem so difficult, so intractable, that we lose sight of the
label: BODY

text: human face associated with their challenges.
label: BODY

text: Sometimes we need to see – to touch – to feel – the real impact of these issues on the
label: BODY

text: lives of citizens in order to better understand them.
label: BODY

text: Sitting in front of you today are five individuals who help us put a “Maryland face” on
label: BODY

text: these issues.  Listen to their stories; they encompass so many lessons that can help us
label: BODY

text: achieve a better place to live, grow, work, and prosper.
label: BODY

text: First, I’d like you to meet Captain Bob Newberry.
label: BODY

text: Captain Bob is 45 years old and lives in Crumpton, Maryland.
label: BODY

text: He has been a Marylander since 1966, when his family moved to Queen Anne’s County
label: BODY

text: from Philadelphia.
label: BODY

text: Captain Bob has been a waterman since he was 15 years old.  For him, being a waterman
label: BODY

text: means “having something in your blood, and never hating to go to work.”
label: BODY

text: Today he fishes, crabs, harvests oysters, farms, and operates one of the few aquaculture
label: BODY

text: farms on the Eastern Shore.
label: BODY

text: Three years ago, he took on extra work as a part-time charter boat captain because it was
label: BODY

text: becoming more difficult to earn his livelihood through fishing.
label: BODY

text: New regulations have harmed his ability to do his job.  A significant drop in the Bay’s
label: BODY

text: oyster and crab populations are also threatening his industry.
label: BODY

text: Several years ago, the value of his average daily oyster catch was up to $2000.
label: BODY

text: Today, a typical catch falls within the $400 - $500 range.
label: BODY

text: He fears that next year’s oyster harvest will be the worst ever.
label: BODY

text: The blue crab is not faring much better.
label: BODY

text: Crabs have become increasingly difficult to catch since the 1980s.  The female crab
label: BODY

text: population has declined an estimated 80 percent since then, and the Chesapeake Bay
label: BODY

text: Foundation reports that the risk to the remaining population is “high and increasing.”
label: BODY

text: Captain Bob is not the only person whose livelihood has suffered as a result.
label: BODY

text: There are 7,000 licensed fishermen who earn their livelihood from the sea in Maryland.
label: BODY

text: They are responsible for an estimated 1 million pounds of harvest annually, representing
label: BODY

text: $86 million in annual income and 3,168 jobs.
label: BODY

text: Many feel that they have been unfairly blamed for the plight of the Bay.
label: BODY

text: They note that the poor water quality has killed off underwater sea grasses, leaving crabs
label: BODY

text: vulnerable to predatory fish.
label: BODY

text: They report that the oyster population is suffering because shells are not being
label: BODY

text: replenished.
label: BODY

text: These hardy individuals are the stewards of our environment.  Many live their entire lives
label: BODY

text: on its banks.  They have an intimate appreciation of its beauty, its species, its problems,
label: BODY

text: and its vitality.
label: BODY

text: It is time to stop blaming them, and to start listening to them.
label: BODY

text: One day, in the not too distant future, there may be no fish, oysters, or crabs unless we
label: BODY

text: achieved measurable progress in cleaning up the Bay.  That means upgrading the 66
label: BODY

text: major municipal sewage treatment plants that cleanse its waters.
label: BODY

text: My capital budget makes a $95 million down payment in this area.  That’s a good start,
label: BODY

text: but we will clearly need additional resources to get the job done.
label: BODY

text: We will need to secure more dollars from the federal government in order to complete
label: BODY

text: this critical task.  That must be a joint effort between the Assembly and this
label: BODY

text: administration.
label: BODY

text: The Chesapeake Bay is central to our identity.  It permeates every aspect of our
label: BODY

text: economic, ecological, recreational life.  Its health affects the livelihood and well being of
label: BODY

text: every Maryland family.
label: BODY

text: We’ve heard the phrase “politics ends at the water’s edge” a lot since 9/11.  I believe that
label: BODY

text: sentiment applies to the waters of the Chesapeake Bay as well.
label: BODY

text: I believe that we can protect it without unduly penalizing the good people who earn their
label: BODY

text: livelihood from it.
label: BODY

text: Now, I’d like you to meet Adela Acosta, principal of Cesar Chavez Elementary School in
label: HH1

text: Prince George’s County.
label: BODY

text: We’ve heard the phrase “no child left behind” in recent years.  Adela was the student
label: BODY

text: who simply would not allow herself to be left behind.
label: BODY

text: Adela was born in Puerto Rico, and later immigrated to New York’s Spanish Harlem.
label: BODY

text: When she enrolled in kindergarten at the age of five, she found it a very scary experience.
label: BODY

text: “A foreign language enveloped me,” she would later write. “English sounded like rocks
label: BODY

text: dropping in a river.  My teachers seemed to think that if they spoke to me in a very loud
label: BODY

text: voice I would understand what they were saying.”
label: BODY

text: Eventually, her teachers labeled her as learning impaired, and she was placed in a special
label: BODY

text: education class in first grade.
label: BODY

text: Fortunately, a social worker discovered her, and she was sent to St. Paul’s parochial
label: BODY

text: school.  There she learned the joy and power of reading as a means of comfort and
label: BODY

text: escape.
label: BODY

text: Her fortunes improved, but she faced other obstacles.
label: BODY

text: Her father – a heroin addict – became blind as the result of a beating by neighborhood
label: BODY

text: bullies.  Adela became his surrogate eyes, reading to him, tending to his needs.  In effect,
label: BODY

text: she became his teacher.
label: BODY

text: One day, she informed her eighth grade teacher that she wanted to teach one day.  The
label: BODY

text: teacher advised her to go into show business because – and I quote – “you people are so
label: BODY

text: good at it.”
label: BODY

text: Fortunately, Adela decided to follow her heart instead.
label: BODY

text: She went on to earn an undergraduate degree in Secondary Education from the University
label: BODY

text: of Kansas, and a Master of Science in Education Degree from the University of Kansas.
label: BODY

text: She has begun doctoral studies in Education Leadership at Nova Southeastern University
label: BODY

text: in Florida.
label: BODY

text: Today, the girl once dismissed as learning-impaired is a nationally recognized educator.
label: BODY

text: President Bush appointed her to the Commission on Excellence in Special Education.
label: BODY

text: And First Lady Laura Bush – a former teacher herself – named her a National Role
label: BODY

text: Model for Education Reform.
label: BODY

text: In 1999 she helped open Cesar Chavez Elementary School.  As principal, she presides
label: BODY

text: over a diverse student body:  47 percent Hispanic, 49 percent African American, and 4
label: BODY

text: percent white.   Ninety-nine percent of her students receive Title I funding.
label: BODY

text: The girl whose potential was once overlooked by her teachers is now looking out for new
label: BODY

text: generations of disadvantaged students.
label: BODY

text: Because of Adela, no child is left behind at Cesar Chavez!
label: BODY

text: Adela’s experiences as a student and an educator have taught her some important lessons.
label: BODY

text: She knows that social promotion policy only hurts kids and sends the wrong message to
label: BODY

text: taxpayers.
label: BODY

text: She knows that every student should compete on a level playing field, and that fully
label: BODY

text: funding the Thornton Commission’s recommendations is critical to her mission.
label: BODY

text: I agree with Adela.  That is why our budget increases education aid $242 million –
label: BODY

text: including $148 million under the Thornton formula.
label: BODY

text: She and I both support the establishment of another commission – Thornton II – devoted
label: BODY

text: to an examination of education policy in Maryland.  Lieutenant Governor Steele will lead
label: BODY

text: this important effort!
label: BODY

text: Finally, she supports a real charter school bill that will encourage competition in our
label: BODY

text: public school system.  Passing charter school legislation is one of my top priorities for
label: BODY

text: this session.
label: BODY

text: It is time for this Assembly to enact a charter schools bill with teeth – one that will give
label: BODY

text: disadvantaged students the opportunity to pursue their dreams.  I ask you to do so this
label: BODY

text: year.
label: BODY

text: Now let me introduce you to Keith Day.
label: BODY

text: Keith is a 45 years old family man.  He and his wife Devorah live in Baltimore.  They’ve
label: BODY

text: been married 14 years and have three children.
label: BODY

text: Keith works as Assistant Manager at the Sheraton Inner Harbor Hotel, where he was
label: BODY

text: named Employee of the Year back in 2001.  He is a member of the New Shiloh Baptist
label: BODY

text: Church.
label: BODY

text: Keith’s story is similar to those of tens of thousands of hard working Marylanders.  But
label: BODY

text: things haven’t always gone easily for Keith.
label: BODY

text: For 25 years, Keith battled an addiction to heroin.  His addiction was so powerful and
label: BODY

text: destructive that he spent three years living on the streets of Baltimore.
label: BODY

text: His life changed when he connected with the Helping Up Mission, a faith-based
label: BODY

text: organization based in Baltimore.
label: BODY

text: Each year, the mission serves 150,000 meals and provides 55,000 beds to poor citizens.
label: BODY

text: However, the mission provides much more than a warm meal and a bed.  It serves hope
label: BODY

text: as well.
label: BODY

text: The mission’s innovative spiritual recovery program enables addicts to find the path
label: BODY

text: towards recovery, employment, and better life skills.
label: BODY

text: The results speak for themselves: program graduates have an 80 percent chance of being
label: BODY

text: employed and sober a year later.
label: BODY

text: Now Keith is clean, sober, and helping people battle their own addictions by volunteering
label: BODY

text: at in the mission.
label: BODY

text: Congratulations, Keith
label: BODY

text: Gun violence – domestic abuse – sexually transmitted disease – lack of educational
label: BODY

text: opportunity – overcrowding in our criminal justice system - over-representation of
label: BODY

text: minority youth in prison – all are directly related to our drug culture.
label: BODY

text: It cuts through every line in our society.
label: BODY

text: It does not care about who you are – or what you do – the color of your skin – or the size
label: BODY

text: of your bank account.
label: BODY

text: It does not discriminate on the basis of race, creed, or color.
label: BODY

text: It makes us bleed.
label: BODY

text: It destroys families – and futures.
label: BODY

text: It strikes fear in the heart of every parent.
label: BODY

text: I am the parent of a three-year-old – I am scared!
label: BODY

text: Our budget spends nearly $136 million on alcohol and drug treatment programs – a 4.2
label: BODY

text: percent increase over last year in FY 04.
label: BODY

text: This is a good start, but we can – and must – do better.
label: BODY

text: We must work together to get non-violent drug offenders out of jail and into treatment
label: BODY

text: programs, where they belong.
label: BODY

text: We must stress early diversion initiatives.  We need to stop routinely condemning so
label: BODY

text: many young offenders to the adult criminal justice system through incarceration and
label: BODY

text: neglect.
label: BODY

text: We will encourage faith organizations of every denomination to offer treatment
label: BODY

text: programs.
label: BODY

text: Faith-based initiatives can achieve on a tiny budget results that the federal government
label: BODY

text: and state of Maryland have been unable to duplicate despite spending billions of dollars.
label: BODY

text: Lieutenant Governor Steele will lead this effort.  It will involve every subdivision in our
label: BODY

text: State – it is a priority for our administration.
label: BODY

text: It’s time to facilitate success, and to empower the problem solvers in our society.
label: BODY

text: Now, let’s meet Michael Taylor.
label: BODY

text: Michael was born in Baltimore in 1958, and attended Hillendale Elementary School.
label: BODY

text: When he was 12 years old, he was placed in the Rosewood Center.
label: BODY

text: Michael spent the next three decades of his life locked away in institutions.
label: BODY

text: “While I was in Rosewood, I didn’t have my freedom,” Michael later said. “I couldn’t
label: BODY

text: decorate my room the way I wanted. I couldn’t call people on the phone without
label: BODY

text: permission.  I was not happy there.”
label: BODY

text: The cost of being institutionalized in Maryland for 30 years is conservatively estimated at
label: BODY

text: $1.6 million.
label: BODY

text: But we can’t calculate the cost it exacted on Michael’s quality of life.
label: BODY

text: Michael was released from Rosewood just four years ago.  He began working for the
label: BODY

text: “Living Free Campaign” and “Stand Up and Speak Out” – two groups that promote
label: BODY

text: freedom and empowerment for the institutionalized.
label: BODY

text: On April 16, 2002, Michael did something he had been waiting to do his entire life.
label: BODY

text: He moved into his very own apartment.
label: BODY

text: He calls his new apartment, located in Towson, his “Freedom Pad,” because nobody else
label: BODY

text: lives there.
label: BODY

text: As Michael gained his freedom, his life started to flourish.
label: BODY

text: He secured a new job with “Best Buddies of Maryland”.  His activism has earned him
label: BODY

text: awards from the State Independent Living Council, Baltimore County Commission on
label: BODY

text: Disabilities, and ARC of Maryland.  He also lobbies on behalf of the disabled, so many
label: BODY

text: of you may know him already.
label: BODY

text: Michael Taylor is an American success story.
label: BODY

text: He is a Maryland success story.
label: BODY

text: And he is a success story for any individual who faces obstacles and challenges in his
label: BODY

text: life.
label: BODY

text: He embodies the success and wisdom of our investment in community-based services.
label: BODY

text: My 2004 budget includes important programs that will help people in similar
label: BODY

text: circumstances live with independence, dignity, and self-sufficiency.  These include:
label: BODY

text: • $5.2 million for the Transitioning Youth Program to help youth with disabilities
label: BODY

text: graduate from school into productive living and working environments
label: BODY

text: • $6.9 million to fund the Developmental Disabilities Waiting List to get people the
label: BODY

text: services they need now
label: BODY

text: • $3.1 million to respond to emergencies faced by families in crisis, such as when
label: BODY

text: an older parent caring for their adult child can no longer provide that care
label: BODY

text: • $16 million to increase the wages that personal care workers receive to assist
label: BODY

text: those with disabilities to ensure a high quality of care.
label: BODY

text: • In total, funding for community services for individuals with developmental
label: BODY

text: disabilities increases by $38.3 million for FY 2004
label: HH1

text: Other important funding initiatives I have proposed assist Marylanders with community-
label: BODY

text: based initiatives, including:
label: BODY

text: • For Seniors:  $7.3 million for 1,000 additional placements for the Medicaid Older
label: BODY

text: Adults Waiver to move people out of nursing homes and back into their homes.
label: BODY

text: • For Youth:  $1 million for a Juvenile Services Drug Court Initiative to help
label: BODY

text: Maryland’s youth get the drug treatment they need without needlessly filling up
label: BODY

text: state juvenile facilities.
label: BODY

text: • For people with mental illness:  An overall $66 million increase for FY 03 and FY
label: BODY

text: 04 for the Mental Hygiene Administration community services budget.  This
label: BODY

text: money will help restore our public mental health system to ensure that it cares for
label: BODY

text: people in the community again.
label: BODY

text: • An overall $66 million increase for FY 03 and FY 04 for the Mental Hygiene
label: BODY

text: Administration community services budget
label: BODY

text: This is a new day in Maryland.
label: BODY

text: We must usher all Marylanders into the 21st Century by moving people out of institutions
label: BODY

text: and into communities, where they live, learn, work and thrive like everyone else.
label: BODY

text: It is time to give every Marylander the tools and opportunities to make their own choices.
label: BODY

text: Our last guest is not with us today.
label: BODY

text: Rio-Jarell Tatum was the son of John S. Tatum and Roxanne Servance.
label: BODY

text: They raised the kind of kid that would make any parent proud.
label: BODY

text: Rio graduated from Baltimore’s Polytechnic Institute’s rigorous A Course in June 2001.
label: BODY

text: At Poly, he was captain of the baseball and soccer teams.  People remember his blazing
label: BODY

text: fastball as well as seeming inexhaustibility on the athletic field.  Others recall his polite,
label: BODY

text: confident, self-assured manner.
label: BODY

text: But his academic prowess stands out the most.  He was a member of the National Honor
label: BODY

text: Society, earning an incredible 3.97 grade point average.  In September 2001 he entered
label: BODY

text: Penn State with a full scholarship.
label: BODY

text: On May 26, 2002, an armed robber shot Rio on a Baltimore street.  He died at Shock
label: BODY

text: Trauma.
label: BODY

text: I wish I’d had the chance to meet this exceptional young man.
label: BODY

text: The things that made a big difference in his life – sports, scholarships, and family – also
label: BODY

text: impacted mine.
label: BODY

text: Here is a kid who did everything right, yet still became a victim of the gun violence
label: BODY

text: sweeping our state’s largest city.
label: BODY

text: Rio’s story should be a wake-up call for all of us.
label: BODY

text: As long as gun-toting criminals roam our streets and communities, no one – not even the
label: BODY

text: best and brightest among us – is safe.
label: BODY

text: That is why it is time to bring Project Exile to Maryland.
label: BODY

text: During its first year in Richmond, Virginia, Project Exile cut violent crime in half.  It is
label: BODY

text: time we bring this successful program to Maryland, too.
label: BODY

text: Thank you, John Tatum and Roxanne Servance, for joining us here today.
label: BODY

text: These are just a few of the fascinating people I met during the journey that ultimately
label: BODY

text: brought Kendel, Drew, Michael, Andrea, and I to Annapolis.
label: BODY

text: As we go about the business of getting our fiscal house in order and making difficult
label: BODY

text: decisions about spending priorities, let’s keep in mind these, and so many other faces of
label: BODY

text: Maryland who depend on us to protect them from injustice – provide a cleaner
label: BODY

text: environment – guarantee a quality education – provide temporary assistance when needed
label: BODY

text: – and make our streets safer.
label: BODY

text: We have an opportunity and an obligation to do great things in each of these critical
label: BODY

text: areas.  For that to happen, we must fully embrace the spirit of cooperation I first
label: BODY

text: encountered in these halls as a young legislator so many years ago.
label: BODY

text: That spirit has stayed with me throughout my public service career, and I am pleased to
label: BODY

text: have the opportunity to bring it back here.
label: BODY

text: Of course, we will disagree at times – sometimes vigorously. But I am confident these
label: BODY

text: disagreements will not undermine our ability to achieve progress.
label: BODY

text: That is what the citizens of Maryland deserve.
label: BODY

text: Maryland faces problems that are daunting, not insurmountable. None will stand when
label: BODY

text: confronted with the energy and enterprise of the people in this room.
label: BODY

text: I look forward to working closely with each of you.  Together we have the chance to
label: BODY

text: change Maryland.
label: BODY

text: Thank you and God bless you.
label: BODY
